text:
March 7, 1956
President H. E. Williams
Southern Baptist College
Walnut Ridge, Arkansas
Dear President Williams:
Reference is made to your letter of February 7, which was addressed to
Washington, D.C., and has just been forwarded to national headquarters
here in Urbana.
We are very pleased to learn that Southern Baptist College will soon apply
for a CP for an educational FM station. Under separate cover, I am send¬
ing some materials which I hope will be helpful to you in planning the station
and putting it into operation. Also, as the association of educational
stations in the United States, we feel that you will be interested in learn¬
ing something about our organization and the services it provides to members.
Incidentally, better than 90$ of all educational radio and television sta¬
tions in the United States belong to the NAEB.
I am enclosing some material which will give you more details about the
Association, and in the materials being sent under separate cover I am
including samples of the reports, surveys and other services we regularly
make available to member stations.
Annual dues in the Association, including a subscription to our monthly
Newsletter and the above mentioned materials, are based on rated transmitter
power, as follows:
Class A - 5 kw and over - $50.00
Class B - 1 - 4*9 kw - 25.00
Class C - Less than 1 kw - 15.00
In addition to the above, member stations enjoy the benefits of our Place¬
ment Service legal counsel, help in meeting day-to-day problems, the op¬
portunity to meet, in seminars, conferences and conventions, with other
educational broadcasters to consider mutual problems, and for the payment
of an additional assessment fee, the use of our tape network.
The NAEB Network, which distributes over 4C0 hours of programming, via
tape recording, per year, is open only to members of the Association.
Through the Network you have an opportunity to broadcast some of the best
educational programs from all over the country as well as a chance to have
some of your better programs receive wider distribution. In addition, being
able to rely on the Network for eight or more hours of programming per week
permits your staff to spend more time on the development of outstanding
programs.
